node.text:
Photo by @didoyamulka 
•
I have learnt over time that the photo is where the light is at. As some of you can recognize that I made this image far away from the main destination which this trail leads to. Halfway into the hike I knew I could not make it to the viewpoint and also this light seemed too good to pass for something else.

In my frantic search for frames, I found these asters right next to the boardwalk and they allowed me to create a composition without stepping on the fragile vegetation. So there I was lying flat on the boardwalk, on my chest, extending my camera to take multiple shots in order to achieve focus throughout. 

As is the case with visitors to any park these days, people soon started flocking to see what animal I was shooting and were disappointed to know that there were no bighorn or grizzlies on that meadow. With the emergence of travel in recent years, visitors to these parks have become extremely demanding in terms of wanting to see these animals during their time in the park. In their bid to see wild animals, people take drastic measures, forget common courtesy, and even compromise their and other’s safety from time to time. I will not understand their plight, the same way they will not understand my fascination with side-lit mountains. 

Let us all enjoy the parks in our own ways. Let’s be less aggressive with nature and other humans when visiting these parks. 
•••
••
•

node.text:
THE WINNER OF OUR BLACKFOOT 2.0 KNIFE GIVEAWAY IS @masoncas CONGRATULATIONS AND PLEASE DM @montanaknifecompany FOR SHIPPING INFO!! 💯💯 KNIFE GIVEAWAY with @montanaknifecompany
•
Montana Strong, Supporting Small Businesses in Montana!
•
We’re teaming up with Montana Knife Company (again 🙌🏼) for an incredible giveaway!
They are a high end knife company based out of Frenchtown, Montana. Owned and operated by Master Bladesmith Josh Smith. 100% USA Made 🇺🇸 Josh has over 30 years of knife making experience under his belt!
Working knives for working people!
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

There will be One winner and the winner will receive a MKC “Blackfoot 2.0” Knife (valued at $300) 
Blackfoot 2.0 is the knife every hiker wants!
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

To enter for a chance to win: 

1. Tag a friend OR leave the comment “MKC”
2. MUST Follow @montanaknifecompany and @glacier_national_park
3. Optional - tag as many friends as you like and those additional tags mean more chances to win!
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

Giveaway ends August 13, 2021 and will be announced on August 14th.
•
The winner will be posted here on this post and in our stories!
The winners will be randomly selected by @montanaknifecompany
•
Good luck everyone and 
it is for USA ONLY 🇺🇸
(Due to high shipping prices)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier_National_Park 🦋 in Glacier National Park with @glaciernps, and @coltons_captures. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Photo by @coltons_captures 
•
Not every day do you get to see a double rainbow, especially with this kind of backdrop. I had just done a 7 hour drive up to Glacier from Stanley, ID and my original plan was just to set up camp early that night and get some rest for a big day in the park the next day. When my first couple spots I had scoped out for camp were already taken I debated on what I should do. There were intermittent showers all afternoon with peeks of sunshine and I thought to myself “maybe I should head into the park, I might get a shot at a rainbow”. Sure enough, the first grand turn of the going-to-the-sun-road I’ll be damned if there wasn’t one, but 2 rainbows! I ended up sleeping in a parking lot in town that night, but it was well worth the grand show Mother Nature put on for me.
•••
••
•

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier_National_Park 🦋 in Glacier National Park with @glaciernps, and @mountains.and.the.wild. May be an image of mountain and nature.

node.text:
Photo by @mountains.and.the.wild
•
Back in Black 🏴‍☠️
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
I’ve wanted this summit for a long time.  As an FYI, this is not a hike.  This is an off trail summit many miles from any trailhead reached on a mountaineering day trip.  It’s a class 5 technical rock climb and we roped up for it.  Reaching this spot required extensive route finding skills, awareness of rockfall hazard, acceptance of fall risk, tolerance for exposure, and a working knowledge of leave-no-trace principles. It’s your responsibility to research park laws, leave-no-trace principles, and safety recommendations thoroughly before participating in any responsible off-trail travel.  Off trail travel is also not always allowed everywhere in Glacier.  Know your physical limits and your wilderness responsibilities, please and thanks ✌🏻
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
I have intentionally omitted the exact location of this photo because the park service confirmed for me this year that they’re still considering closing off-trail access in this general area due to erosion and other environmental concerns.  I would therefore urge those of you who know where this is to refrain from commenting about the location in an effort to help preserve this fragile high place and the current access to it.  Thanks!
•••
••
•

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Glacier_National_Park 🦋 on August 05, 2021 tagging @glaciernps, and @jchnpaul. May be an image of nature, lake and twilight.

node.text:
Photos by @jchnpaul 
•
While in a gift shop on our second day in the park I saw a picture of this mountain in a calendar and instantly researched its name and where it was located. I had to photograph it. Five days later we arrived to a lake with this mountain just in the background, but for the next 48 hours it was completely covered in clouds. Judging by the forecast I thought for sure I wasn’t going to see anything other than the base of it. 
Our last night in this location the clouds parted and I ran out to this muddy point after setting up my camera for my wife. We yelled back and forth to get a few long exposures and I ran back to where she was in the dark with a huge grin on my face.  Mount Gould, glad I got to see you. (Swipe to see it in all its glory and the pic of the calendar)⠀

•••
••
•

Photo by Glacier_National_Park 🦋 in Glacier National Park with @traveltrachs, and @glaciernps. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Photo by @traveltrachs 
•
This was by far the hardest hike we did on our 2 week trip. We started from the Swiftcurrent Motor Inn and hiked up to Swiftcurrent Mountain. Online, it says this is a 16 mile hike. Leslie's Apple watch says we went 23 miles. I don't know which is accurate, but that's a pretty big difference! It sure felt like 23. 

We started early and we didn't see anyone else on the trail for 7 miles! About 2 miles in, we heard some rustling to our right just off the trail. We discovered it was a large bear, most likely a grizzly. We got out our bear spray and began to turn back toward the trailhead, however, it seemed the bear was headed that direction. We decided to continue on, with bear spray in hand. The bear wasn't bothered by us and after a minute or so of continuing on, we didn't see or hear from the bear again. 

On this hike, we were making sure to talk to each other and clap when headed around blind turns the entire time so if there were bears on the trail, they would be aware of our presence. We had already been doing this when we ran into that first bear, and I believe that caused the bear to not be startled by us. 

About another mile up, we came around a blind turn to a bull moose on our left who was staring at us as soon as he was in our sight. He must've heard us as well 😄 

We started this hike just before 7am and didn't finish til around 4pm. This was my favorite view we experienced in Glacier National Park and we earned this one!
•
#swiftcurrentpass

•••
••
•

node.text:
Photo by @alexarmitage_ 
•
Glacier National park is something else. I’ve been quite a few places but never been on a drive like the one in Glacier. Don’t hesitate to get up there, even if it’s far away. It’s a must see drive in your lifetime. 
•••
••
•
